title: 114_hr3006
content: The Act may be cited as the "Helping Save Americans' Health Care Choices Act of 2015". The table of sections for this Act is provided. The "Helping Save Americans' Health Care Choices Act of 2015" includes provisions such as eliminating the requirement for coverage under a high deductible health plan, increasing the contribution limit to an HSA, allowing both spouses to make catch-up contributions, using HSA funds for health insurance premiums, enhancing portability of HSAs, treating certain physician fees as medical care, allowing Medicare recipients to have HSAs, and using FSA funds for long-term care insurance premiums. Additionally, the Act repeals limitations on deductions for non-prescription drugs from tax-preferred accounts. Repeal of additional tax from distributions from HSAs and MSAs, repeal of limitation on health flexible spending arrangements under cafeteria plans. Elimination of requirement for coverage under a high deductible health plan. The text chunk discusses the definition of an eligible individual and eligible health plan under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including membership in a health care sharing ministry. It also mentions the elimination of the requirement for coverage under a high deductible health plan. The amendments made by this section replace "deductible health plan" with "eligible health plan" in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These amendments will apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Increase the maximum contribution limit to an HSA. The maximum contribution limits to an HSA are increased for self-only and family coverage, with adjustments for inflation. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment date. The amendments to contribution limits for HSAs apply to taxable years after the enactment date. Both spouses can now make catch-up contributions to the same HSA account. The new amendment allows both spouses over age 55 to contribute 200 percent of the usual amount to one HSA account if the spouse is not already a beneficiary. Effective for taxable years after enactment. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow HSA funds for health insurance premiums. Effective for taxable years after enactment. SEC. 6 increases portability of Health Savings Accounts. (a) Treatment After Death of Account Beneficiary.--Section 223(f)(8)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to treat a surviving spouse or lineal descendant as the designated beneficiary of a health savings account after the death of the account beneficiary. (b) Qualified Medical Expenses.--Amends section 223(d)(2) to specify qualified medical expenses for health savings accounts. The term 'qualified medical expenses' refers to payments for medical care not covered by insurance. The amendments apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include pre-paid physician fees as medical care. This applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 8 provides a special rule for certain medical expenses incurred before the establishment of an account. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include pre-paid physician fees as medical care for taxable years after the Act's enactment. A special rule is provided for certain medical expenses incurred before the establishment of a health savings account. The amendments made by this section apply to health savings accounts established, contributions to and distributions from health savings accounts after the enactment of this Act. Medicare recipients can now contribute to Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) under the amended Internal Revenue Code. Medicare beneficiaries in Medicare Advantage MSAs can also contribute their own money to their accounts. Additionally, Flexible Spending Account (FSA) funds can now be used for long-term care insurance premiums. These changes apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to allow employer-provided coverage for qualified long-term care services through flexible spending arrangements. This change applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment allowing employer-provided coverage for qualified long-term care services through flexible spending arrangements applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 11. REPEAL OF LIMITATION ON DEDUCTIONS FOR NON-PRESCRIPTION DRUGS FROM TAX-PREFERRED ACCOUNTS. SEC. 12. REPEAL OF ADDITIONAL TAX FROM DISTRIBUTIONS FROM HSAS AND MSAS. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding HSAs, Archer MSAs, Health Flexible Spending Arrangements, and Health Reimbursement Arrangements. Effective dates for these amendments are specified for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 12. Amends the Internal Revenue Code by reducing the additional tax on distributions from HSAs and Archer MSAs. The tax rate is lowered from 20% to 10% for HSAs and from 20% to 15% for Archer MSAs. These amendments apply to distributions made after the enactment of this Act. Section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by removing subsection (i) and redesignating subsections (j), (k), and (l) as subsections (i), (j), and (k) respectively. These amendments will apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of this Act.
